title: asda-extends-10-percent-discount-blue-light-workers---get
story: Asda has extended its  percent discountto emergency workers with a Blue Light Cardthis festive season.The supermarket is thanking key workers from the NHS, emergency services, social care and armed forces by extending the discount until January , . The discount is available to redeem across all of Asdas  stores and can be used on food and drink, George at Asda clothingand homeware, toys, gts and optical too.“This Christmas has been particularly tough for our emergency services, so we wanted to say a heartfelt thank you for everything they continue to do by extending our discount in stores until the end of January," said Derek Lawlor, Chief Merchandising Officer at Asda.,  px px  rgbamargin: pxmax-width: pxmin-width: pxpadding: width: .%width: -webkit-calcwidth: calc"" fill"#"View this post on InstagramtranslateY"translateX translateYwidth: .pxflex-grow: margin-right: pxmargin-left: px"translateY"translateY rotate"""translateX"A post shared by Blue Light Card While Tom Dalby, CEO at Blue Light Card, added: “It has been incredible that Asda has supported our members with a great in-store offer in the run up to Christmas, helping them save at one of the most expensive times of the year.“We are delighted that Asda have now extended their offer, recognising the work that our members do day-in, day-out to support our communities.”Which brands offer discounts with a Blue Light Card AOBoohooBuyagtFootasylum GymsharkHalfordsHotpointKitchenAidLove HoneyMyproteinNew LookRay-BanRiver IslandSamsungShark Home UKSports DirectThe Fragrance ShopShop the Big January sale here.You can also find out more about getting a Blue Light Cardvia our explainer.

title: outstanding-achievements-borderers-recognised-queen
story: FOUR women from the Scottish Borders have been awarded British Empire Medals in the Queen’s New Year’s Honours list.Mother and daughter Helen Ramsey and Lynsey Cargill from Ancrumwere recognised for services to the community in Ancrum, Roxburghshire during COVID-.The pair who run the Ancrum Pantry supported the community during the COVID- pandemic providing an essential supply of food and utilities and establishing a delivery service for residents who were sick or self-isolating.The shop became a leline for many particularly the elderly, vulnerable and those with underlying health conditions. Villagers were able to phone requests for provisions and have them delivered to their door the following morning, along with the uplt or delivery of letters and parcels.The shop was kept open  days a week, and the shop’s Facebook page became a vital means of communication, signposting help available to residents.Also recognised was Josephine Robson from Broughton for services to Foster Care in TweeddaleFor over  years she cared for disadvantaged local children, in addition to raising her own family, using her home as a focus for a happy group of children, providing stimulus to help develop their creativity.She was also was active in the successful campaign to prevent closure of the local primary school, and has volunteered as an adult literacy tutor spending hours working with adult learners.Shelagh Mary Weir was also recognised for services to Sport in the Scottish Borders.

title: take-hiking-winter
story: POLICE in the Scottish Borders have issued advice to hill walkers and mountaineers on what to dothey find themselves in dficulty and also what kit should be taken.Officers say you should stay calm and make sure you and your group are not in any immediate danger.Locate your exact position and give first aid to anyone injured. Keep warm and decide whether youll be able to turn back, find shelter or stay where you are and call for help.It is a good idea to let a responsible person know the details of where you are going and what you are doing.Having the right kit is essential not only to keep you warm and dry but to keep you safe. The kit you buy, and use should reflect the type of activity that you intend to do and the conditions you may face.Outdoor shops will be able to provide you with advice on what you may need. The following list details the essentials for general hillwalking:Wear well-fitting boots suitable for the terrain you will walk on and the activity you plan to do. Gaiters may be beneficial for areas that are particularly boggy or where ticks may be present.A layered system of clothing is always best as you can adjust for the temperature better. The base layer should wick away the moisture with an insulating mid-layer and a breathable waterproof jacketand trousers.A hat and gloves should be packed also. Avoid any materials that may absorb water e.g. cotton T-shirt or jeans. If possible, wear clothing, especially a waterproof jacket that is a bright colour, so that you can easily be found in the event of an emergency.Always, always have a map and compass and know how to use it. Smartphones or GPS are excellent navigation aids but should not be relied on solely. Make sure you have the right map for the area you are walking in and check that your compass is working each time before you set off.Only use a rucksack big enough for the items that you will need. You may have to keep the contents in a waterproof bagthe rucksack is not waterproof..removeA whistle, head torch , survival bag, group shelter, first aid kit and mobile phone are essential. If you walk on your own, consider using a Personal Locator Beacon.Walking poles are very useful as they save energy and limit damage to the knees. Don’t forget to pack according to the weather so a sun hat, sun glasses and sun screen along with midge repellent net should be packedappropriate. Take enough food for the whole of your journey and have some packed as emergency rations. Carry a water bottle. You will usually be able to top this up from mountain streams, but it’s best to check availability in advance so you don’t run short.Winter conditions in Scotland are prevalent for many months of the year. Additional items may be required such as extra clothing, helmet, ice axe, crampons, winter boots and avalanche equipment.

title: unwanted-christmas-presents
story: ADVICE Direct Scotland, the country’s national advice service, has been running a Christmas campaign to remind shoppers of their consumer rights when ing or exchanging unwanted Christmas gts.From purchasing the wrong size of jumper to receiving two copies of the same book, the post-Christmas period results in lots of requests for refunds or gt swaps.The Consumer Rights Act gives everyone the legal right to either get a refund for goods that are of unsatisfactory quality, unfit for purpose or not as described, or to get a repair – depending on how long the items have been owned.Consumers also have more rights when shopping online and for most online s the regulations state that you can cancel an online order up to  days after receiving it, followed by a -day period in which you can send it back.Consumer rights include:The legal right to either get a refund for goods that are of unsatisfactory quality unfit for purpose or not as described or to get a repair – depending on how long you’ve owned it. From zero to  days, you are entitled to a full refund for goods that are of unsatisfactory quality.For most online s, Consumer Contract Regulations state that you can cancel an online order up to  days after receiving it, followed by a -day period in which you can send your .If you have purchased an item that turns out to be faulty or damaged, your consumer rights entitle you to a full refund within  days. If yourexceeds the -day threshold, then you are no longer covered by the ‘short-term right to reject’ and may only be entitled to a repair, replacement, or partial refund of your item.You are not automatically entitled to the same -day refund with digital purchases such as games, movies or music. Butyour digital purchase does notas advertised, does not play run properly, or is otherwise faulty, you can ask the retailer to repair or replace it.Many shops will accept s of non-faulty items, but there are exceptions including personalised items, perishable goods such as food and flowers, and products that have been worn such as earrings, make-up, toiletries, underwear or swimwear..removeColin Mathieson, spokesperson for Advice Direct Scotland, said: “Even with the best intentions when it comes to buying gts, we can’t always get it right.“From purchasing the wrong size of Christmas jumper to ordering the incorrect colour of phone case, many of us rely on the robust s policies of our favourite retailers, and the ability to swap a gt for something more appropriate when required.“Consumers have extensive rights when it comes to s and refunds, and it is always worth remembering these.“Anyone in Scotland who has any questions about their rights can contact us for free, impartial and practical advice.”Anyone in Scotland who wants more advice on their consumer rights can contact consumeradvice.scot for free on   . Specialist advisers are available from am to pm, Monday-Friday, excluding public holidays.

title: covid-restrictions-now-apply-gyms-libraries-museums
story: All Live Borders activities across their sports, fitness, libraries, museums and venues will have a one-metre physical distancing requirement until  January.The updated guidance may result in some activities and venues having reduced capacity, so where appropriate the charity recommend that customers book in advance to avoid disappointment.Safety of customers and staff remains their priority and they will continue to take the appropriate measures to ensure a safe and spacious environment the existing strict hygiene regimes and improved venue ventilation will continue to keep all activities as safe as is possible.Indoor adultcontact sport and physical activity will not be permitted and Live Borders will be in touch with all those affected by this new guidance.Indoor hospitality venues will reintroduce physical distancingbetween groups .Live Borders continue to encourage all customers to test regularly and wear face covering as required. Additional detailed sector specic guidance will continue to be issued and we will keep you fully informed.

title: a7-close-two-locations-works-say-road-officials
story: THE A is set to close in two locations over the coming weeks, according to officials.The road will shut from Teviothead to the Johnnie Armstrong Gallery between .pm and am each night from Monday, January  to Friday, January  – excluding Saturday and Sunday.The A will then be closed from south of Hawick High School to Sandbed Roundabout between the same times from February  to February .:Borders primary school targeted by vandals as £.k damage caused to gardenA ersion route will be signposted between Hawick and Canonbie via the A, B and B.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotland’s south east network manager, said: “These surfacing improvements will help to address the defects on this section of the A and will greatly improve the experience for motorists.“It is essential for safety that we close the road during these works, however we’ve arranged for the project to take place overnight to minimise the impact.“We thank motorists and the local community in advance for their patience and understanding. We’ll do all we can to complete the work as quickly and safely as possible.”

title: first-minister-announces-changes-covid-restrictions
story: A NUMBER of changes to Covid restrictions in Scotland come into effect from today .Anyone who test positive for Covid will be allowed to exit self-isolation after seven daysthey have no fever and record two negative lateral flow tests.The first of these tests must be taken on the sixth day after testing positive and then at least  hours later.In addition, household contacts of people with the virus will now be allowed to take a lateral flow test every day for seven days rather than going into self-isolation.This applies to everyone in the household under the age of  or anyone over that age who has had the first, second and booster Covid jabs.If one of these tests is positive, self-isolation will then be required.Anyone identied as a close contact who is over  and four months old and not fully vaccinated will still be asked to self-isolate for  days and take a PCR test.Restrictions, such as the limit on large scale events and closure of nightclubs, remain in place until  January.Also, people who do not have Covid symptoms but get a positive result using a lateral flow test no longer have to book a PCR test.The announcement was made by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon who told MSPs taking part in special virtual session of Holyrood yesterday that the changes are “signicant and not completely without risk”.She said: “At this stage of the pandemic they strike an appropriate balance between the continued importance of self-isolation in breaking chains of transmission, and reducing the disruption self-isolation causes in the economy and critical services.”Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross responded: “I welcome the U-turn on self-isolation rules, which Scottish Conservatives have been calling for since day one. We said then the policy was not sustainable.“Every other part of the United Kingdom made this change, but Scotland was left as an outlier. Why did the First Minister take so long to make this change .remove“I also welcome the changes to testing rules, which are sensible and in line with the approach across the United Kingdom.”

title: borders-peer-peer-charity-receives-1-000-donation
story: SBHA, together with Jewson Partnership Solutions , Sidey, and Keith McLean Carpets, are supporting local men’s mental health charity ANDYSMANCLUB, by donating a total of £,.The UK-wide charity has recently launched a free peer-to-peer support group for all men in the Scottish Borders, based in Galashiels.Julia Mulloy, Chief Executive at SBHA said: “SBHA is pleased to be supporting ANDYSMANCLUB which provides men in the Scottish Borders with a safe and friendly space to meet up and talk.“We recognise that, particularly at this time of year, the impact of poor mental health can be devastating for iniduals and their families.“We value the work that ANDYSMANCLUB is doing to challenge the stigma of men’s mental health by encouraging men to talk.”Jenner Millar, Partnership Account Manager – East Scotland for Jewson Partnership Solutions commented: “Giving back to our communities where we live and work is a priority for Jewson Partnership Solutions. In partnership with SBHA, we are delighted our contribution will help fund a vital service for men in the Scottish Borders.”Alex McClintock, Project Development Champion, ANDYSMANCLUB added: “A huge ANDYSMANCLUB thank you to SBHA, Jewson Partnership Solutions, Sidey and Keith McLean Carpets, for this very generous donation. This money will not only help us to grow the Galashiels Club, but also to expand further in the Borders. If you or someone you know needs someone to talk to, especially at this time of year, please reach out to ANDYSMANCLUB as we’re here to help.”

title: coronavirus-borders-records-170-cases-24-hours
story: MORE than  cases of coronavirus have been recorded in the Borders in the last  hours, the latest figures show.The Scottish Government published updated statistics at pm today .And the data shows that the region has now seen , cases of COVID- since March last year – a rise of  since yesterday.There are  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of coronavirus, according to the figures – seven more than yesterday.Scotland has now surpassed one million cases since the pandemic began – the national total now stands at ,,.

title: exciting-new-offer-live-borders
story: LIVE Borders are offering members the opportunity to join one of their online reading groups.The groups meet once a month, and there are two types of groups to choose from.Members download the selected reading group eBook from Borrowbox and the group will meet once a month to discuss their thoughts and observations.Members of the download reading group will require an eLibrary membership and access to Borrowbox to download onto their device.Members will come together to discuss their current read whether it be fiction, non-fiction, a magazine article or even a play.The group offers the opportunity to learn about dferent authors and broaden your own reading horizons.Members are given the chance to evaluate and share what they have been reading with the rest of the group.The reading groups can accommodate  people in each group and will run on the following days every month:First Monday in every month - Read Your Own Group .-. - Download Group .-.First Thursday in every month - Read Your Own Group .-. - Download Group .-.Second Thursday in every month - Download Group .-. -For more information or to enquire about availability and how to book your place email: libgalashiels@liveborders.org.uk

title: iceland-offers-50-off-favourite-brands-including-heinz-birds-eye
story: After splurging a little too much at Christmas, your bank account will thank you for shopping Icelandsup to  percent off sale. Whether youre looking to save a few pennies this January or youre looking for some inspiration in the kitchen, weve got you covered. The supermarket has slashed its prices across some of your favourite brands including Birds Eye, Comfort, Surf, Heinzand more. Weve put together a list of some of our top picks so that you dont have to go far to find a bargain. A woman shopping on her phone. Credit: PA Iceland up to  percent off sale Dolmio Bolognese Smooth Tomato Pasta SauceIceland is offering customers free pastawhen they buy When your purchase three of the Dolmio pasta sauce jarsfor just £, you can get your pasta for free. The deal includes its bolognese sauce as well as its smooth tomato sauce, tomato and cheese bake sauce and more.Shop the meal deal now.Birds Eye Chicken Dippers If youve given up on Veganuary already, these chicken dipperswill be perfect treat for you and the whole family.The -dipper bagis now half price, down from £.Pick up a bag for £..Comfort Jasmine and Strawberry Fabric Conditioner Iceland has slashed the prices of its favourite brands including Comfort. This Jasmine and Strawberry Fabric Conditioneris available for half price, down from £. You can now take on  as fresh as a daisy for just £..Iceland   percent British Beef Quarter PoundersThese  percent Beef Quarter Pounderswill make you feel like summer has come already. The four-packhas been reduced by  percent from £.. You can treat the familynow for just £.. Surf Tropical Lily  in  capsules Washing CapsulesEveryday essentials shouldnt break the bank and with Icelands up to half price sale, they dont have to.These  in  capsuleshave been reduced by  percent, down from £..Get  washesfor £..Shop the full Iceland up to  percent off sale via the Iceland website.

title: new-advice-travellers-entering-scotland
story: THE rules on pre-departure testing for travellers entering Scotland have been changed.Fully-vaccinated travellers ing to Scotland from abroad will no longer have to take pre-departure Covid tests or self-isolate upon arrival until they have received a negative result.The change in rules came into effect at am this morning. Travellers are still required to take a test on or before day two after arriving in the UK, which can be a lateral flow device rather than a PCR test. This rule comes into effect from am on Sunday morning.Anyone who tests positive on their lateral flow test will need to isolate and take a free confirmatory PCR test.The new measures apply across the UK after agreement between the UK Government and the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.Transport secretary Michael Matheson said: “Given the rapid spread of Omicron last year it was essential that we took immediate steps to protect public health in Scotland, particularly with regards to international travel.“We still have signicant concerns over Omicron, but we recognise that, now it is the most dominant strain in Scotland and across the UK, it is sensible to review the measures currently in place.“We also fully understand the impact of the restrictions on staff and businesses in the travel and aviation sectors and these changes demonstrate our commitment not to keep measures in place any longer than necessary.“However, people still need to be extremely careful when travelling and to remember that both our and other countries’ Covid- requirements can change at short notice as things can evolve very quickly.“People should therefore ensure they have travel insurance and carefully check their booking terms and conditions, as well as ensuring compliance with the latest regulations for the country being visited.”

title: brighton-boss-graham-potter-not-surprised-davy-proppers-early-retirement
story: Brighton boss Graham Potter admits he was not overly surprised by Davy Propper’s “brave” decision to quit football at the age of just .Midfielder Propper, who rejoined Dutch club PSV Eindhoven from Albion last summer, announced his retirement on Tuesday, revealing he no longer felt comfortable in the sport.The former Holland international said he gradually lost his love for the game during his four-season stay with the Seagulls.Potter had y conversations with the club’s one-time record signing before his Amex Stadium departure and detected a change in the player prior to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.“It doesn’t come as a massive surprise to me the announcement,I am honest. I know Davy was struggling and found it tough,” said Potter.“A Dutch guy living in the UK in lockdown, so he didn’t get to see much of his family and friends and that was an added pressure.“I would say it was even a little bit before with Davy. You could tell he wasn’t quite himself, wasn’t quite what was needed and there are many things for that.“We spoke atwith Davy and supported him through a tough time in his le, really.“It is not easy to start that process of thinking, ‘maybe football is not the right thing for me’, and it is a big decision to make and I think Davy has made a brave one.”Albion paid PSV a reported £.million for Propper following their promotion to the Premier League in .He was a regular for the first three years – and won  of his  international caps while with the Seagulls – but managed just seven top-flight appearances in the - campaign before ing to Eindhoven.“For me he was a great guy to have around, always professional, always trying,” said Potter.“But that is le sometimes, these things happen and people want to do dferent things and I fully respect that.“He is a grown man, Davy. He had all our support while he was here and we wish him the best now.”Potter, who has Brighton in the top half of the Premier League table at the midway point of the season, is preparing for Saturday’s FA Cup third-round tie away to Championship club West Brom..removeThe one-time Baggies player is targeting a cup run at the expense of his former club.“It’s a great club West Brom, I had three and a bit years there so I know the people of the area, they’re great supporters and back their team,” said Potter, who was at the Hawthorns from  to .“We want to try and go through, we’re going to try and pick a team that will help us do that.“The guys are all making themselves available to play. The boys want to play, they’re in a good moment of form and want to do their best.“It’s by no means an easy game. We have got to fight to go through – I have full respect for them.”.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brighton boss Graham Potter not surprised by Davy Propper us early retirement

title: nearly-quarter-ambulance-handovers-delayed-least-30-minutes
story: Nearly one in four patients arriving at hospitals in England by ambulance last week waited at least  minutes to be handed over to AE departments, new figures show.Some , delays of half an hour or more were recorded across all hospital trusts in the seven days to January , according to NHS England.This was % of all arrivals by ambulance, up from % the previous week and equalling the level recorded in early December.Some % of patients waited more than an hour to be handed over – again, the joint highest so far this winter.vw,vw,px, px"A handover delay does not always mean a patient has waited in an ambulance. They may have been moved into an AE department, but there were no staff available to complete the handover.The figures give a snapshot of the pressure hospitals in England were facing in the period immediately after Christmas, however.Analysis of the data by the PA news agency shows that University Hospitals Birmingham Foundation Trust reported the highest number of delays of at least  minutes last week , followed by North West Anglia , University Hospitals of Leicester , and Barking, Havering  Redbridge University Hospitals .University Hospitals Birmingham also topped the list for delays of more than an hour , followed by University Hospitals Bristol  Weston , Gloucestershire Hospitalsand University Hospitals of Leicester .A total of , NHS staff at hospital trusts in England were absent for Covid- reasons on January , up % on the previous weekand more than three times the number at the start of December .The total includes staff who were ill with coronavirus or who were having to self-isolate.vw,vw,px, px"Separate figures published by NHS England on Friday show that % of patients with coronavirus in hospital in England on January  were being treated primarily for Covid-.This is down from % a week earlier and % at the start of December..removeBut the total number of patients treated primarily for Covid- is continuing to increase, up from , on December  to , on January .The number of people in hospital with Covid- but being treated primarily for something  rose week on week from , to ,..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Nearly a quarter of ambulance handovers delayed by at least  minutes

title: france-takes-eu-reins-push-sovereignty
story: French President Emmanuel Macron has pledged to boost Europe’s strategic power and sovereignty, as France formally took the reins of the -nation bloc for the next six months with big ambitions.A leitmot of the French presidency over the next six months will be the need for greater autonomy for the region.Mr Macron has been championing the idea since he took power five years ago and will use the rotating presidency of the Council of the EU, which sets the political agenda of the region, to try to put it into practice.vw,vw,px, px"French President Emmanuel Macron, right, and European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen at a press conference after a meeting at the Elysee Palace Speaking during a joint press conference with the head of the EU’s executive arm, European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, Mr Macron said the bloc will finalise this semester the EU’s so-called strategic compass, its geopolitical strategy that focuses on defence capacity building.“It will allow us to have a common European position at Nato and to act together in a more co-ordinated way,” Mr Macron said, adding that he wants to develop Europe’s defence industry and increase the bloc’s technological autonomy.Amid lingering tensions between Russia and Ukraine, Mr Macron added that the EU will also build proposals for “an architecture of European security”, which is still largely dependent on the US and Nato.Mr Macron and Ms von der Leyen earlier paid tribute to two leading European figures at France’s famed Pantheon, honouring the memories of Simone Veil and Jean Monnet.vw,vw,px, px"Giant portraits of late French politician Simone Veil, right, and diplomat Jean Monnet, left, are displayed outside the Pantheon in Paris Veil was a Holocaust survivor who repeatedly broke barriers for women in politics.She spearheaded the fight to legalise abortion in France and was the first woman president of the European Parliament..removeMonnet was a founding father of the European Union.Both Mr Macron and Ms von der Leyen wore masks during the visit inside the domed building, amid a wave of coronavirus cases that somewhat overshadowed the beginning of the French tenure and caused trouble for the French leader ahead of the arrival in Paris of EU officials.Mr Macron, who is expected to seek re-election later this year, made headlines earlier this week by using rude language in reference to the country’s minority of unvaccinated people.In an interview with a newspaper, Mr Macron described his strategy for pressuring vaccine refusers to get coronavirus jabs by using the word “emmerder” – rooted in the French word for “crap” and meaning to rile.His vulgar language dominated news broadcasts and provoked angry reactions from his political rivals.To move things forward on the continental stage on the vast array of touchy topics he wants to tackle, Mr Macron will need to adopt a more consensual tone with his EU counterparts.vw,vw,px, px"French President Emmanuel Macron, third right, speaks with European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, third left, during a meeting at the Elysee Palace With the coronavirus pandemic flaring in Europe and amid diplomatic tensions at the external borders of the EU, Ms von der Leyen said she was pleased “that a country with the political weight and experience of France assumes the presidency of the council at such a delicate moment”.“Because the voice of France speaks loud and clear, and France has Europe at heart,” she said.Among other main themes France wants to promote are the introduction of an EU minimum wage, a carbon tax on imported products and the reform of the EU’s fiscal rules.France also wants to accelerate discussions between member states to find a consensus on the stalled overhaul of the bloc’s asylum system..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: France takes EU reins with push for more sovereignty

title: covid-scotland-report-lateral-flow-test-result
story: Lateral flow tests are becoming part of our every day lives as we learn to live with the presence of Covid. With results coming through in less than  minutes, its a quick and easy way to checkyou are carrying the virus. But did you know we were meant to be logging the results of these tests Reporting the result of each lateral flow test you do helps the government keep track of the presence of Covid in the community, and can help to identy outbreaks on a local level.Test results can be logged on the UK Government website - heres how to do it.How to report your Covid lateral flow test resultTo log your Covid lateral flow test result, first visit this website.You should report your result to the NHS every time you take a lateral flow and as soon as possible after the result as come through after  hours you will no longer be able to report the outcome of your test. It gives you the option to sign in and create an account, where the details of all your tests will be stored. If you are running short on time you can continue as a guest, but your test results will not be saved for future. The form will then ask you some administrative questions, including who you are reporting the results for and which country you live in. It will also ask you why you have taken the test. You then have to enter the test ID number which can be found below the QR code on the testing strip. Alternatively,you are on your phone, you can scan the QR code. Once you have completed the form, you should recieve a confirmation text which you can use as proof to enter events in Scotland, some of which require evidence of a negative test.

title: banks-open-new-years-eve-see-full-list-festive-opening-hours
story: Its the last day of  meaning you might be wanting to run some errands before the end of the year is up. However,heading to the bank is on your list, make sure to do so early with many closing their doors in the afternoon in time for the Hogmanay celebrations.Heres what you need to know about bank opening hours on New Years Eve...Are banks open on New Years eve this year  Heres when banks close on New Years eve:Natwest - all branches close at pmRBS - all branches close at pmBarclays - all branches close at pm Bank of Scotland- all branches close at pmVirgin Money UK - all branches close at pmHSBC - all branches close at pmSantander - all branches close at pmHalax - all branches close at pmAre banks open on January  and   New years day and January  fall on a weekend this year, like Christmas and Boxing day. In Scotland, January  is a bank holiday, however this day is not celebrated in other UK countries. Natwest - closed January RBS - closed January Barclays - closed January   Bank of Scotland - closed January   Virgin Money UK - closed January   HSBC - closed January   Santander - closed January   Halax - closed January

title: hogmanay-mean-start
story: Hogmanay is once again upon us, but do you know what its all about The Scottish holiday marks the turn of the year and is celebrated on the final day of December. Heres everything you need to know...What is Hogmanay Hogmanay is the Scots word for the last day of the old year and marks the celebration of the New Year in the Scotland.It is normally followed by further celebration on the morning of New Years Day. The origins of Hogmanay are unclear, but it may be derived from Norse and Gaelic observances of the winter solstice.Customs y throughout Scotland usually include gt-giving and visiting the homes of friends and neighbours. What is first foot First foot is observed on New Years Day, and involves being the first person to cross the threshold of a friend or neighbour and often involves the giving of symbolic gts such as coal, shortbread, whisky, and black bun intended to bring dferent kinds of luck to the householder.The first-foot is supposed to set the luck for the rest of the year. Is Hogmanay celebrated in England Hogmanay refers to the New Years Eve celebrations in Scotland, while in England they simply call it New Years Eve.This year in Scotland, Hogmanay parties like the Edinburgh street party have been cancelled due to Covid.

title: take-christmas-tree
story: Christmas day is officially behind us, and some people might already be thinking about taking down the decorations. However, did you know that according to tradition the decorations should be kept up into January Heres what you need to know...When should you take down your Christmas tree According to the twelve days of Christmas tradition, your Christmas decorations should be taken down on the twelfth and final day. The twelve days of Christmas is associated with Christianity, with the twelfth night celebrating the arrival of the Three Wise Men who followed the star of Bethlehem to bring their gts to baby Jesus.However, there is some debate as to whether the twelfth day falls on January  or . The Church of England counts from Christmas Day, meaning the Twelfth Night  falls on January .However, the Catholic Church only starts counting from Boxing Day meaning January  is the twelfth day, as well as Epiphany. Epiphany is a Christian holiday that marks the baptism of Jesus. Ultimately, it is up to you when to take down your decorations, with some people preferring to have a fresh start going into the new year. Last year, many people chose to keep their lights up well into February to try and keep the festive spirit going during the January lockdown.

title: mokrun to return live in 2022
story: For the last two years, because of the Covid- pandemic, the annual race has been held virtually, with competitors completing a K or half-marathon distance inidually, within their home area, between two given dates.However, the MOKRUN committee has announced the event – including the junior races and the famous MOKRUN ceilidh – willin May , in adherence with any Covid guidance in place at the time.The junior races will be on Saturday May  from pm, with the half-marathon and K kicking off at .am the following day, on Sunday May .The MOKRUN and Sports Council Ceilidh will take place on the Sunday evening, with doors opening at pm. Due to Covid restrictions, the number of ceilidh tickets available will be limited.Entries go live for both senior races and the ceilidh at am on Sunday January  via Entry Central.The race, one of the biggest events in Kintyre#s sporting calendar, was established .It has grown in popularity due to its picturesque location and fantastic atmosphere, as well as the post-race celebrations of Danish pastries and ceilidh dancing.And it has been voted as the UK#s top race in Runner#s World magazine multiple times, meaning places typically sell-out quickly.

title: argyll crews roar to rally success
story: The final round of the Marshall Construction Scottish Tarmac Rally Championships saw two Argyll crews head north to the Milltown stages in Elgin.This venue was being used for the first time in many years and was the culmination of a lot of hard work by the organising team.A number of drivers and co-drivers were vying for the top spot in the important final championship standings.In his Fiesta R, Alister Inglis, from Stonehaven, had been dominant in the earlier parts of the season and was probably favourite to grab the overall championship.Argyll, however, sent two crews into this final round with a realistic chance of causing an upset.Lochgilphead#s Jamie Miller, originally from Tayinloan – although now #up the road# – is very much involved in everything that happens in Argyll rallying.He and co-driver Ian McCulloch headed to Milltown with the best chance yet of clinching a championship in their Citroen C R Max.Things didn#t get off to a great start for Jamie with the car losing its brakes meanin they limped through a very slippy stage one and then, in his own words, #drove like a pensioner# for much of the rest of the day.What had been a brilliant season for the team was mildly soured by mechanical issues but Jamie takes some solace from finishing third overall for the  championship.It should be noted that Jamie#s long-suffering co-driver Ian sealed second spot in the overall co-driver#s championship on the day too.Father and daughter combo Innes and Kirty Mochrie also took to the roads, travelling six hours to get to Elgin on the Friday.Once again, the #Mighty # had defied the odds and embarrassed a lot of the much more expensive and powerful machinery and they, too, were sitting on the start line of stage one of the final round knowing they could, with the right combination of results, walk away as overall champions.A rare mistake on stage one saw the car bounce off a tyre or two but get away with it by missing the important components and only dislodging the light bar.A steady run from there on saw the crew finish third in class on the day which was enough for Innes to capture second overall driver in the championship, while Kirsty capped a fantastic first full season with the overall co-driver#s title.Alister Inglis held on to the overall title spot, despite a hairy moment when the Fiesta lost a wheel in the final stage of the day. That aside, it was a strong year for the driver.Argyll rally fans are looking forward to a full  season, Covid permitting, in conjunction with Dunfermline Car Club and the new main title sponsors Burnside Piling.CAPTIONS:Jamie Miller and Ian McCulloch in their Citroen CR MAX. NO_ctarmacrallyThe trustybelonging to Innes and Kirsty Mochrie. NO_ctarmacrallyOverall championship winners Alister Inglis and Colin Inglis in their Fiesta, with a full complement of wheels. NO_ctarmacrally

title: wild swimmers take the plunge in peninver
story: North Atlantic Ocean waves battered the hardy souls who took to the sea for a refreshing dook.But the swimmers, who brave Kintyre#s seas all throughout the year and are used to battling the worst elements of nature, took it in their stride.CAPTIONS:Ten members of South and West Kintyre Wile n Mild Swimmers took to the sea on New Year#s Day.
